article.title: Skeleton-Based Action Recognition Using Spatio-Temporal LSTM Network with Trust Gates

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the spatial dimension of the ST-LSTM network represent?
choices: The flow of time in the skeletal sequence.
The activation values of the hidden states.
The sequential order of different body joints within a frame.
The number of layers in the stacked ST-LSTM network.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the ST-LSTM unit, what is the role of the hidden representation (hj-1,t) received from the previous joint at the current time step?
choices: It provides temporal context information about the same joint from previous frames.
It represents the input data for the current joint at the current time step.
It provides spatial context information from neighboring joints at the same frame.
It determines how much the content of the previous state contributes to the current state.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is a tree-structure based traversal preferred over a simple chain order for feeding skeletal data to the ST-LSTM network?
choices: Tree structures are easier to implement and require less computational resources.
Tree structures can handle missing or occluded joint data more effectively.
Tree structures better represent the kinematic interdependencies between body joints.
Tree structures allow for faster training and convergence of the network.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the function of the trust gate (Tj,t) in the cell state update equation?
choices: To determine how much the content of the previous states contribute to the current state.
To control the contribution of newly arrived input data based on its estimated reliability.
To modulate the input data before it is used to update the memory cell.
To learn how the output of the LSTM unit should be derived from the internal memory cell.
